author: Pavel Alpeyev
title: Toshiba Drops After Report of 200 Billion Yen Asset-Sales Plan
text:
Toshiba Corp. fell to the lowest since 2013 in Tokyo trading after a report it may sell assets worth 200 billion yen ($1.7 billion) amid an internal accounting probe that the company has said will lead to earnings writedowns.
The stock fell as much as 6.5 percent to 369.1 yen, the lowest intraday since January 2013, as of 9:25 a.m. in Tokyo. The shares are down 28 percent this year, compared with a 9.3 percent gain in the Topix stock benchmark.
Asset sales may include part of its stake in atomic power plant maker Westinghouse Electric, the Nikkei newspaper reported Thursday without saying where it got the information. Toshiba had said as early as 2012 that it is considering a sale of as much as 36 percent of that business.
There is no change to the plan to sell part of the Westinghouse stake, spokesman Hirokazu Tsukimoto said Thursday, in response to a Nikkei report.
Toshiba on May 8 withdrew its earnings forecasts and canceled the year-end dividend citing irregularities related to “percentage of completion” estimates used on infrastructure projects. The company is also investigating its visual products, PC and chip businesses.
Writedowns of past profit will rise to more than 100 billion yen, a person familiar with the matter said July 4. That’s almost double the previous estimate by the company, which has said it expects to complete a third-party probe of its accounting by the middle of this month.
Suspended Ratings At least eight analysts have suspended their ratings on the company’s shares amid uncertainty about the probe’s scope. The company initially said it was examining accounting at units for nuclear, hydroelectric, wind-power equipment, air-traffic control and railway systems, then widened the probe to include personal computers and other businesses.
The company intentionally delayed booking losses, the Nikkei reported Thursday, without saying where it got the information. Toshiba is not aware of a deliberate delay in accounting for losses, Tsukimoto, the company spokesman, said Thursday.
Toshiba also plans to overhaul appliance operations, looking for Southeast Asia partners and cutting subsidiaries, the Nikkei reported. It may also announce new steps for its PC business and changes to chip operations.
